Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide the Phase 2 systems engineering for the Global Environment for Network
Innovations (GENI) project. GENI, a virtual laboratory for exploring future internet technologies
and protocols at scale, creates major opportunities to understand, innovate and transform
global networks and their interactions with society. Via the flexible and dynamic deployment of
experiments onto common infrastructure, GENI re-imagines the methodology of both network system
research and of potential early deployments and evaluation. It enables repeatable experiments
on large, complex, networked systems At scale demonstrations of transformational ideas
increases the opportunity for significant socio-economic impact.

At the start of the GENI program it was not clear that GENI was technically feasible. An early major goal was to show
its feasibility. To this end, the GPO started a series of rapid, community-created prototypes via ?spiral development?
so that hands on experience could drive its evolution. Each GENI spiral is 12 months long, and aims to drive down
specific technical and programmatic risks. This proposal supports the engineering activities of spirals 4, 5 and 6.
The task categories associated with the proposal are:
a) Experiment support and direct aid to the research teams attempting to use the GENI prototype, including training
and tools.
b) Continued progress towards full Integration and Operations of the current GENI prototype including
deployment of GENI racks, enhancing the integration with Internet 2 and National Lambda Rail, additional
WiMax integration, campus expansion with the goal of having between 100 to 200 campuses ?GENI enabled?, and
transition for 24x7 operations managed by Indiana University.
c) Formalization and documentation of the GENI architecture.
d) Systems Engineering work including security analysis of the GENI infrastructure, instrumentation and
measurement tools and infrastructure, and subcontract technical management.

Broader Impact: The engineering process of building GENI has directly engaged the newest generation of
faculty in students in a large-scale systems project. The experience of building a large-scale system
is an educational opportunity that is providing direct benefit to the US computer research community. GENI
is already being used as an instrument for research. This proposal supports and broadens the availability
and usability of the research instrument.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Note: GENI is supported by multiple NSF awards. This outcomes report summarizes overall GENI-related outcomes. The specific work of this award, "GENI Engineering Activities, Phase 2," shifted project emphasis from building GENI to using GENI in research.

GENI's Goals

The Global Environment for Network Innovations - GENI - is a suite of research infrastructure that comprises a distributed laboratory deployed across the United States. (See Figure 1.) GENI aims to transform experimental research in networking and distributed systems by providing a suite of infrastructure for "at-scale" experiments in future internets.

GENI supports a wide variety of experiments, including the following:

  • Experiments ranging from small to “at-scale” experiments.
  • Both experiments that are compatible and experiments that are incompatible with today’s Internet.
  • Not only controlled, repeatable experiments, which which will greatly help improve our scientific understanding of complex, large-scale networks, but also trials of experimental services that ride atop or connect to today’s Internet and that engage large numbers of users.
  • A variety of classroom and research experiments.

Although GENI’s goal is to support “at-scale” experiments on future internets, our plan has never been to build a separate, parallel set of infrastructure “as big as the Internet,” which is clearly infeasible. Instead, the approach has been to “GENI-enable” existing testbeds, campuses, regional and backbone networks, cloud computation services, and commercial equipment to be programmable, virtualized and sliceable, so that they could support end-to-end experiments. 

GENI's Results

GENI has addressed its initial purpose of supporting innovative research, and it has gone beyond these goals in a number of ways. The GENI project office and the GENI community have built GENI with an initial at-scale deployment now in place. GENI’s use in the classroom is lowering the barrier for laboratory-based learning in computer science education. It is increasingly finding application in data- and compute-intensive domain sciences. Furthermore, GENI infrastructure is supporting advanced application development in areas of societal impact, through initiatives such as US Ignite. (See Figures 2 and 3.)

GENI continues to see explosive growth in usage for both research and education – over 7,700 unique users have turned to GENI, allocating over 217,000 GENI configurations. (See Figure 4.) GENI’s user base reaches more than 180 US universities and over 30 countries. (See Figure 5.)

Building upon the engineering activities performed under this award, the initial nationwide GENI deployment is nearing completion, incorporating over 60 GENI racks at universities, regional and backbone networks, and partner institutions across the US. GENI hardware and concepts are increasingly extending beyond GENI proper and being integrated with campus scientific computing infrastructure. More researchers from the GENI community are publishing their results – the bibliography of GENI-relevant publications now includes hundreds of entries.

Educators continue to develop GENI-based curriculum and employ GENI in their classrooms. Over 55 different instructors now regularly use GENI in their classes. In the last complete semester (Spring 2016), instructors used GENI in at least 25 different courses with total enrollment of hundreds of students.

Future Directions

The GENI community and GENI technology are playing a vital role in leading the development of research cyberinfrastructure. Key GENI concepts are increasingly embedded into new projects, such as the NSF Future Cloud research platform, and the recent NSF CISE "Looking Beyond the Internet" Steering Group Report identifies GENI as a thought leader for future research infrastructure. Similarly, the central GENI notions of slicability and deep programmability are finding their way into future internet and distributed cloud research testbeds worldwide. (See Figure 6.)

As GENI is being created and improved, it is engaging an unusually wide range of participants from a cross-section of US institutions. This community is designing and developing GENI technology, deploying GENI on their campuses, and using GENI in their research. Many universities are applying GENI in their courses, with the potential to transform totally how experimental computer science is taught and learned.

Perhaps most important to us, the GENI community, is that the newest generation of networking and distributed systems researchers have enthusiastically taken up research leadership roles in an ambitious project of national importance. We would like to congratulate the numerous academic and industrial groups – both Principal Investigators and many graduate students – who play a role in defining and shaping GENI.

Mark Berman, GENI Project Director
